freedom_fighters.name: Harriet Tubman
key_facts: Led over 300 enslaved people to freedom
Never lost a single person on Underground Railroad missions
Served as spy for Union Army during Civil War
Founded home for elderly African Americans
freedom_fighters.content_angle: The woman who never lost a passenger

freedom_fighters.name: Frederick Douglass
key_facts: Self-taught to read and write while enslaved
Published three autobiographies
Advised President Lincoln during Civil War
First African American nominated for Vice President

freedom_fighters.name: Sojourner Truth
key_facts: Born Isabella Baumfree in New York slavery
Escaped slavery with infant daughter
Famous 'Ain't I a Woman?' speech
Recruited Black troops for Union Army
freedom_fighters.content_angle: The voice that couldn't be silenced
freedom_fighters.sensitivity_notes: Highlight intersectionality of race and gender struggles

underground_railroad.name: William Still
key_facts: Helped over 800 enslaved people escape
Kept detailed records of Underground Railroad operations
Published 'The Underground Rail Road' in 1872
Called the 'Father of the Underground Railroad'
underground_railroad.content_angle: The record keeper who preserved history

underground_railroad.name: Levi Coffin
key_facts: Quaker who helped over 3,000 enslaved people
Called 'President of the Underground Railroad'
Worked with both white and Black conductors
Continued activism after Civil War
underground_railroad.content_angle: The white ally who risked everything
underground_railroad.sensitivity_notes: Show interracial cooperation while centering Black agency

intellectuals_writers.name: Phillis Wheatley
key_facts: Kidnapped from West Africa as child
Learned to read and write English, Latin, and Greek
Published 'Poems on Various Subjects' in 1773
Corresponded with George Washington
intellectuals_writers.content_angle: The genius who proved Black intellectual equality
intellectuals_writers.sensitivity_notes: Address both achievement and tragedy of enslavement

intellectuals_writers.name: David Walker
key_facts: Wrote 'Walker's Appeal' in 1829
Called for immediate end to slavery
First Black American to advocate for armed resistance
Influenced later abolitionists like Frederick Douglass
intellectuals_writers.content_angle: The radical voice that sparked a movement
intellectuals_writers.sensitivity_notes: Handle discussion of resistance with historical context

religious_leaders.name: Richard Allen
religious_leaders.primary_achievement: Founder of African Methodist Episcopal Church
key_facts: Born into slavery, purchased his freedom
Founded first independent Black denomination
Established schools and mutual aid societies
Consecrated as first AME bishop
religious_leaders.content_angle: The minister who built a movement
religious_leaders.sensitivity_notes: Highlight community building and institutional development

inventors_innovators.name: Benjamin Banneker
key_facts: Self-taught mathematician and astronomer
Helped survey Washington D.C.
Published almanacs with astronomical calculations
Wrote to Thomas Jefferson about racial equality
inventors_innovators.sensitivity_notes: Emphasize intellectual contributions and challenges to racism

inventors_innovators.name: Norbert Rillieux
key_facts: Born free in New Orleans to white father and enslaved mother
Invented multiple-effect evaporator for sugar
Revolutionized sugar industry worldwide
Studied engineering in Paris
inventors_innovators.content_angle: The genius who sweetened the world
inventors_innovators.sensitivity_notes: Address complex racial identity and international education
